estion "Find the sum of all possible integral values of $k$ such that the area of the triangle formed with edges along the line $y=\frac{2}{3}x+5$, the $x$-axis, and the line $x=k$ is less than 20", we need to follow these steps:
Determine the points of intersection of the line $y=\frac{2}{3}x+5$ with the $x$-axis.
(This will help identify the height of the triangle.)
Express the area of the triangle formed by the line $y=\frac{2}{3}x+5$, the $x$-axis, and the line $x=k$ in terms of $k$.

(The formula for the area of a triangle in this case is $\frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$ where height is the $y$-value of the line at $x=k$ and base is the distance from the $y$-axis to $x=k$.)
Set up an inequality for the area to be less than 20 using the expression derived in step 2.
(This will translate into a condition on $k$.)
Solve the inequality for $k$.
(This step involves algebraic manipulation to find the range of values that $k$ can take.)
Find all integral values of $k$ within the range identified in step 4.
(We need to list down the integers that satisfy the inequality condition.)
Compute the sum of all those integral values.
(Add all the integral values of $k$ together to get the answer.)
Verify if slight changes in the boundary values of $k$ keep the area under 20 or affect the final sum.
(Check whether the closest non-integral values of $k$ around the limits give an area exactly equal to or just greater than 20, to ensure all cases are accounted for.)
